metadata.title: Redefining the Mexican genus Diguetinus Roewer, 1912 (Opiliones, Phalangioidea, Globipedidae) based on morphology and molecular phylogenetic data, with the redescription of Diguetinus spinulatus (Banks, 1898) stat. restit.

metadata.title: Adverse Outcome Pathway Wiki RDF
metadata.description: This dataset is the RDF generated from the AOP-Wiki data release (aopwiki.org/downloads). It was generated using a Jupyter notebook that is available on GitHub (github.com/marvinm2/AOPWikiRDF), and the process and additional description of the RDF have been published (doi.org/10.1089/aivt.2021.0010).

grants.title: Innovative Nanoinformatics models and tools: towards a Solid, verified and Integrated Approach to Predictive (eco)Toxicology (NanoSolveIT)
An Integrated European ‘Flagship’ Program Driving Mechanism-based Toxicity Testing and Risk Assessment for the 21st Century
OpenRiskNet: Open e-Infrastructure to Support Data Sharing, Knowledge Integration and in silico Analysis and Modelling in Risk Assessment
The Virtual Human Platform for Safety Assessment

metadata.notes: Funded by the European Union's Horizon 2020 (EU 2020) research and innovation program under grant agreement no. 681002 (EU-ToxRisk), grant agreement no. 814572 (NanoSolveIT), grant agreement no. 814425 (RiskGONE), EINFRA-22-2016 program under grant agreement no. 731075 (OpenRiskNet), and VHP4Safety, which is funded by the Netherlands Research Council (NWO) 'Netherlands Research Agenda: Research on Routes by Consortia' (NWA-ORC 1292.19.272)

data.title: Application of Generative AI in Health Systems: A Comprehensive Review of Innovations and Implications

metadata.title: Decoding Circulating Neutrophil Phenotypes in Triple-Negative Breast Cancer via Optimized Single Cell RNA Sequencing
metadata.description:
Neutrophils are emerging as key regulators of tumor biology, influencing cancer progression, immune evasion, and therapeutic response. However, their transcriptomic characterization remains challenging due to low RNA content, limiting confident discrimination from other leukocyte populations at the single-cell level. To address this, we developed a robust analytical framework for single-cell RNA-seq data, calculating a neutrophil score for each cell based on two curated neutrophil marker gene panels and excluding cells expressing non-neutrophil marker genes.  

White blood cells were isolated from liquid biopsies of 9 breast cancer patients (3 luminal B and 6 triple-negative) and 6 non-malignant donors, sequenced, and analyzed to profile 84 neutrophils from triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) and 128 control neutrophils. TNBC neutrophils displayed significant upregulation of migration-associated genes (–log₁₀ adjusted p ≈ 3) and respiratory complex genes (p < 1 × 10⁻⁹) compared with controls. Furthermore, TNBC and luminal breast cancer neutrophils shared highly similar transcriptomic profiles, both clearly distinct from those of healthy donors.  

These findings demonstrate that breast cancer induces a shared transcriptional reprogramming of circulating neutrophils across subtypes, suggesting systemic immune modulation linked to tumor presence. This work provides a validated framework for precise neutrophil identification and functional characterization in single-cell studies and lays the foundation for dissecting their mechanistic roles in cancer progression.

data.title: Decoding Circulating Neutrophil Phenotypes in Triple-Negative Breast Cancer via Optimized Single Cell RNA Sequencing

metadata.title: All data and code for "Sequence and chemical specificity define the functional landscape of intrinsically disordered regions" (2026)
metadata.description:
This Zenodo repository reflects a time-of-acceptance deposition of code and data associated with the manuscript Sequence and chemical specificity define the functional landscape of intrinsically disordered regions. 

Full citation information:

Sequence and chemical specificity define the functional landscape of intrinsically disordered regions

Iris Langstein-Skora1*, Andrea Schmid1*, Frauke Huth2*, Drin Shabani1, Lorenz Spechtenhauser1, Mariia Likhodeeva3, Franziska Kunert3, Felix J. Metzner3, Ryan J. Emenecker4,5, Mary O. Richardson5,6, Wasim Aftab7, Maximilian J. Götz1,8, Sarah K. Payer1,9, Niccoló Pietrantoni1,10, Valentina Sjeničić1,11, Sakthi K. Ravichandran1, Till Bartke12, Karl-Peter Hopfner3, Ulrich Gerland2, Philipp Korber1†, Alex S. Holehouse4,5†

1 Biomedical Center (BMC), Division of Molecular Biology, Faculty of Medicine, LMU Munich, Martinsried, Germany
2 Physics of Complex Biosystems, Technical University of Munich, Garching, Germany
3 Gene Center, Department of Biochemistry, LMU Munich, Munich, Germany
4 Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biophysics, Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis, MO, USA
5 Center for Biomolecular Condensates, Washington University, St. Louis, MO, USA
6 Present address: Moderna, Inc., Cambridge, MA, USA
7 Core Facility Bioinformatics, Biomedical Center (BMC), Faculty of Medicine, LMU Munich, Martinsried, Germany
8 Present address: Gene Center, Department of Biochemistry, LMU Munich, Munich, Germany
9 Present address: Proteros Biostructures GmbH, Martinsried, Germany
10 Present address: Scuola Superiore Sant’Anna, Pisa, Italy
11 Present address: Faculty of Biology, University of Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia
12 Institute of Functional Epigenetics, Helmholtz Zentrum München, Neuherberg, Germany

*These authors contributed equally
†Corresponding author. Email: pkorber@lmu.de, alex.holehouse@wustl.edu

The associated manuscript is pending formal acceptance, but the full citation information will be updated on the associated GitHub link that mirrors the code and content and most of the data in this Zenodo repository.

Link: https://github.com/holehouse-lab/supportingdata/tree/master/2026/Langstein-Skora_2026 

About

Please seed the README.md file associated with the uploaded ZIP file. 

Contributors

All authors listed above should be considered contributors to this work.

Licensing

DATA is shared under CC BY 4.0 (Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International) (link here)

CODE is shared under the MIT License. (link here)

Funding

Please see the ACKNOWLEDGEMENT section on the final publication for funder acknowledgement.

File map

The text below maps how each data element in the main/extended data maps to code and data within the repository. This information is also included in the main README.md associated with the .zip file.

 

Figure 1

  • A - Schematic of conservation vs. disorder in a single protein (no data)
  • B - figure_1/disorder_vs_conservation_correlation.ipynb
  • C - figure_1/disorder_vs_conservation_correlation.ipynb
  • D - figure_1/disorder_vs_conservation_correlation.ipynb
  • E - Schematic of plasmid shuffling assay (no data)
  • F - Data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables)
  • G - Schematic showing constructs (data from dilution plates)
  • H - figure_1/abf1_idr2.fasta - amino acid sequence provided

Figure 2

  • A - Schematic of chemical conservation vs. sequence conservation
  • B - figures_2/composition_conservation.ipynb
  • C - figures_2/alignment_schematic_figure_2c.ipynb
  • D - growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables). Tree structure from Feng et al. Scientific Reports 2017.
  • E - growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables) with protein function taken from UniProt and/or SGD entries on the proteins listed.

Figure 3

  • A - Schematic showing folded domain and IDR; growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).
  • B - Schematic showing what sequence "shuffling" means; growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).
  • C - Schematic showing where subregions are being shuffled (schematic to scale); growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).
  • D - figure_3/linear_analysis.ipynb
  • E - Schematic highlighting relative positions of the essential motif, Abf1-G4-like subregion, and $Gal4G4 subregion.
  • F - Files in figure_3/em_structural_prediction/
  • G - growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).
  • H - Schematic (no data)
  • I - growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).
  • J - growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).
  • K - growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).
  • L - growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).
  • M - growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).

Figure 4

  • A - Schematic of motif and context (top) and chemical vs. sequence specificity (bottom)
  • B - figure_4/coarse_grained_simulation_analysis.ipynb
  • C - growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).
  • D - figure_4/coarse_grained_simulation_analysis.ipynb
  • E - growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).
  • F - growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).
  • G - growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).
  • H - growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).
  • I - figure_4/composition_analysis_fig_4.ipynb
  • J - growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).
  • K - growth data from dilution plates (see supplementary figures and supplementary tables).

Figure 5

  • See readme in figure_5/
  • A - Schematic of FINCHES-based analysis
  • B - Schematic of in silico evolution, with individual intermaps generated using figure_5/evolution/in_silico_evo.ipynb
  • C - figure_5/evolution/signal_vs_noise_final.ipynb
  • D - Schematic showing error-prone PCR workflow
  • E - Schematic of expected behavior
  • F (top) - figure_5/evolution/error_prone_pcr_analysis.ipynb
  • F (bottom) - figure_5/evolution/error_prone_pcr_vs_in_silico_final.ipynb

Figure 6

  • See readme in figure_6/
  • A - Schematic of MNase-seq
  • B - figure_6/6B/MNase_coverage_Abf1_fig6B.xlsx
  • C - Schematic of Anchor Away (no data)
  • D - Schematic of ODM-seq (no data)
  • E - figure_6/6E/6E_Kubik_responder_sites.tsv
  • F - figure_6/6F/
  • G - figure_6/6F/
  • H - `Schematic of overall model (no data)

Supplementary figures 1 and 2

Growth data are provided in the viablity_data/ directory, with two large PDFs that report original images for growth plates.

For completeness, we also provide all supplementary tables in the supplementary_tables/ directory (supplementary_tables_2025_11_30.xlsx).

metadata.title: Comparative Supply Chain Risk Management for Biologics and Pharmaceuticals (messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccines and gene therapies): FDA, Health Canada, and EMA Approaches
metadata.description: This study examines the comparative Supply Chain Risk Management (SCRM) frameworks applied to biologics and pharmaceuticals, specifically messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccines and gene therapies, across the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), Health Canada, and the European Medicines Agency (EMA). Biologics and advanced therapies present unique manufacturing and distribution challenges due to their complexity, sensitivity to environmental conditions, and reliance on high-integrity cold-chain systems. Using a comparative case study methodology supported by Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA), this research evaluates how regulatory agencies manage risks related to production, quality assurance, and distribution. Findings indicate that harmonized risk management practices grounded in International Council for Harmonisation (ICH) Q9 (Quality Risk Management) and Q10 (Pharmaceutical Quality System) principles can reduce supply disruptions by approximately 30% and improve compliance outcomes. The study highlights the growing emphasis on data integrity, Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) compliance, and cross-border cooperation, especially under emergency pathways such as the FDA’s Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) and EMA’s accelerated approval.

metadata.title: A Critical Re-evaluation of "An ATP-gated molecular switch orchestrates human messenger RNA export" by Hohmann., Nature 2025; doi: 10.1038/s41586-025-09832-z
metadata.description:
This deposit provides a comprehensive, multi-dimensional, and rigorously structured critique of the 2025 Nature article “An ATP-gated molecular switch orchestrates human messenger RNA export” by Hohmann, Graf, Tirian, Pacheco-Fiallos, Schellhaas, Fin and colleagues. The critique evaluates the study from structural, biochemical, cellular, statistical, computational, conceptual, and evolutionary perspectives, offering the most extensive independent post-publication assessment of the proposed mechanism to date.

The original paper introduces an ambitious model in which the DEAD-box helicase DDX39 is positioned as an ATP-gated molecular switch sequentially directing TREX loading, TREX release, TREX-2 engagement, and nuclear pore targeting for virtually all human mRNA transcripts. Because this mechanism implies a fundamental reorganization of long-standing paradigms in mRNA export biology, its evidentiary and conceptual robustness warrant exceptionally thorough scrutiny.

This commentary presents a full figure-by-figure and extended-data–by–extended-data analysis, demonstrating that the proposed mechanism is not supported by the data shown in the publication. Structural differences between ATP- and ADP-bound states are extremely subtle and lack the conformational magnitude required for a switch-like model. Biochemical assays lack reproducibility, quantification, and appropriate controls. Imaging analyses lack raw data, standardized acquisition, and statistical evaluation. RNA-sequencing results show minimal transcriptomic effects inconsistent with disruption of a universal export determinant. Extended Data Figures reveal internal inconsistencies, insufficient replicates, and contradictory phenotypes.

Beyond the empirical shortcomings, the critique evaluates the biological plausibility of the model. The proposed mechanism conflicts with established roles of TREX, TREX-2, NXF1, Dbp5, Gle1, nucleocytoplasmic directionality checkpoints, mRNP heterogeneity, nuclear spatial organization, and evolutionary conservation across eukaryotes. It additionally fails key energetic, architectural, and phenotypic plausibility tests.

Together, these analyses show that the central claim of an ATP-gated master switch for mRNA export is incompatible with known principles of RNA biology and lacks the evidentiary foundation necessary for acceptance. The commentary aims to support scientific transparency, strengthen post-publication peer review, and encourage rigorous methodological standards for mechanism-level claims affecting core processes of gene expression.

The deposit includes the full structured commentary, with numbered sections, detailed textual analysis, and systematic evaluation of all figures and supplementary materials. It is intended as a resource for researchers in RNA biology, structural biology, gene expression, and scientific integrity.
keywords: mRNA export, DDX39, ATP-gated switch, TREX complex, TREX-2, nuclear pore complex, RNA helicase, gene expression, nucleocytoplasmic transport, post-publication peer review, structural biology, RNA sequencing, RNA biology, export mechanism, critique

data.title: A Critical Re-evaluation of "An ATP-gated molecular switch orchestrates human messenger RNA export" by Hohmann., Nature 2025; doi: 10.1038/s41586-025-09832-z

metadata.title: Integrative Approaches in Medicinal Plant Research: Combining Traditional Knowledge with Modern Science
metadata.description:
Medicinal plants remain a cornerstone of global health systems, especially in regions
where traditional knowledge forms the primary basis of healthcare. In recent decades,
scientific interest in botanicals has accelerated due to growing recognition of their therapeutic
potential, biochemical diversity and relevance to drug discovery. This review synthesizes
traditional ethnobotanical knowledge with modern scientific approaches, highlighting the
interplay between cultural heritage and contemporary research methodologies. It emphasizes
how integrative frameworks involving ethnobotany, phytochemistry, molecular biology,
biotechnology, bioinformatics, pharmacology and clinical sciences are transforming medicinal
plant research. Key advances such as metabolomics, DNA barcoding, high-throughput
screening, machine learning-assisted compound prediction and evidence-based validation are
discussed. Furthermore, the review addresses global challenges including biopiracy, habitat
loss, climate threats, lack of standardization and ethical issues in knowledge appropriation.
The paper concludes by outlining future directions that promote sustainable utilization,
community-driven research and development of plant-based therapeutics through
interdisciplinary strategies.

metadata.title: Position paper on cooperation between NFDI and de.NBI & ELIXIR-DE
metadata.description:
Summary

de.NBI & ELIXIR-DE are central pillars of the German research data infrastructure and, with the de.NBI cloud, offer cloud-based services, storage solutions, and resources for scientific research and education. They support scientific work with computing power, data management, and security, especially for sensitive data such as human genome data. However, they face challenges: Long-term financing of hardware and personnel is crucial to meet the associated, ever-growing demands. In addition, there is a lack of needs-based services, including for long-term data archiving, which will have to be coordinated in the future with other infrastructures such as the National High Performance Computing Network (NHR) and other actors, e.g., within the European Open Science Cloud (EOSC). The increasing demand for powerful GPUs for AI and HPC requires continuous investment, often at the expense of renewing existing systems. At the same time, the development of secure working environments (SPE/TRE) is necessary to comply with EU and national guidelines and to protect sensitive data.


Cooperation with the National Research Data Infrastructure (NFDI) and the National High Performance Computing Network is crucial: The de.NBI Cloud is closely linked to the NFDI consortia and has been supporting them in the development and operation of sustainable research data infrastructures from the very beginning. The NHR provides the NFDI consortia with HPC infrastructures for use in AI, HPC, and data applications. Closer cooperation between NFDI, NHR, and de.NBI Cloud would not only improve the integration of technologies in the transition area between cloud, HPC, and AI, but also offer a sustainable and needs-based option for integrated research data management, even across disciplines.

Strategically, de.NBI & ELIXIR-DE with the de.NBI Cloud are key players within the EOSC Federation and for the national EOSC node in Germany. Their further development requires sustainable funding, technological adaptation, and close cooperation with NFDI, NHR, and European initiatives to ensure Germany's research competitiveness and independence. Only in this way can research continue to work with state-of-the-art technology and under secure conditions in the long term.

creators.name: Wagener, Harald
creators.affiliation: Berlin Institute of Health at Charité - Universitätsmedizin Berlin
